results.title: Magic Michael
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: A story film for children, based on Louis Slobodkin’s book. “Michael wasn’t happy just being my brother, he wanted to be something - something or other.” Michael turns himself into anything from a pup to a bear or a chair. This story about an imaginative little boy is told in rhyming couplets, with visuals based on the original illustrations to the book. Storyteller: Owen Jordan.
results.description: A story film for children, based on Louis Slobodkin’s book. “Michael wasn’t happy just being my brother, he wanted to be something - something or other.” Michael turns himself into anything from a pup to a bear or a chair. results.title: Magic lantern slides
results.brief_description: Magic lantern slides are as varied as they are enchanting. While early slides featured line etchings on glass plates, lanternists were soon hand-painting them to give projections vibrancy and depth. When photography arrived in the 1840s, photos started appearing on lantern slides.

constellations_primary.name: Space, sci-fi and cinema fakes
constellations_primary.description: Magic lantern slides were used to entertain and educate audiences in home, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations and scientists revealed the latest discoveries.

results.description:
Magic lantern slides are as varied as they are enchanting. While early slides featured line etchings on glass plates, lanternists were soon hand-painting them to give projections vibrancy and depth.

In the 1820s, copperplate printing processes allowed an image to be stamped on glass. This led to mass slide production from the mid-1800s to the 1920s – particularly of toy slides, which were printed with decals and bordered with colourful edges to protect children’s hands.

The arrival of photography in the 1840s advanced things: photos printed on glass brought real-life scenes to life. But technology didn’t diminish the craftsmanship of lanternists, who still retouched worn slides by hand.
description_for_label:
Magic lantern slides are as varied as they are enchanting. While early slides featured line etchings on glass plates, lanternists were soon hand-painting them to give projections vibrancy and depth.

In the 1820s, copperplate printing processes allowed an image to be stamped on glass. This led to mass slide production from the mid-1800s to the 1920s – particularly of toy slides, which were printed with decals and bordered with colourful edges to protect children’s hands.

The arrival of photography in the 1840s advanced things: photos printed on glass brought real-life scenes to life. But technology didn’t diminish the craftsmanship of lanternists, who still retouched worn slides by hand.

results.title: Magic lantern projectors
results.brief_description: Magic lanterns were made in all shapes and sizes from materials as diverse as biscuit tins and brass to mahogany and nickel. They were even mass-produced as children’s toys in the 19th century.

constellations_primary.name: Cautionary tales and magic lantern projectors
constellations_primary.description: Early magic lantern projections depicted cautionary religious scenes and fairytales, just like cinema did in its infancy.

results.description:
Early magic lantern projections depicted cautionary religious and supernatural scenes, like sinners roasting in Purgatory and Death wielding a scythe. Luckily, magic lanterns weren’t used only by clergymen but also by a wide variety of entertainers and educators in homes, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations, scientists revealed the latest discoveries and charlatan magicians spooked audiences with dancing skeletons.

Magic lanterns were made in all shapes and sizes from materials as diverse as biscuit tins and brass to mahogany and nickel. They were even mass-produced as children’s toys in the 19th century.
description_for_label:
Early magic lantern projections depicted cautionary religious and supernatural scenes, like sinners roasting in Purgatory and Death wielding a scythe. Luckily, magic lanterns weren’t used only by clergymen but also by a wide variety of entertainers and educators in homes, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations, scientists revealed the latest discoveries and charlatan magicians spooked audiences with dancing skeletons.

Magic lanterns were made in all shapes and sizes from materials as diverse as biscuit tins and brass to mahogany and nickel. They were even mass-produced as children’s toys in the 19th century.

results.title: Magic in the air
results.brief_description: A simple explanation with animated diagrams shows the basic principles of television. This film takes you behind the scenes of television studios at Radio City, the construction of the iconoscope which is the sender and the kinescope which is the receiver.
results.description: A simple explanation with animated diagrams shows the basic principles of television. This film takes you behind the scenes of television studios at Radio City, the construction of the iconoscope which is the sender and the kinescope which is the receiver.

results.title: Magic Flute
results.creator_credit: Gayle Thomas, Derek Lamb and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Lyrical animation of the magical events which occur when various children play a flute, evoking both pleasant scenes of flowers and unpleasant ones of witches and bats, according to the personality of the child. Sound film without words. (Awards: Palo Alto; Columbus)
